Nick Gall wrote:
> Sorry to ask such a naive question, but WHY exactly is it a misuse of PUT?
> 
> Here's the example Amazon uses:
> 
> PUT /destinationObject HTTP/1.1
> Host: destinationbucket.s3.amazonaws.com 
> <http://destinationbucket.s3.amazonaws.com>
> x-amz-copy-source: /sourcebucket/sourceObject
> Authorization: AWS 15B4D3461F177624206A:ENoSbxYByFA0UGLZUqJN5EUnLDg=
> Date: Wed, 20 Feb 2008 22:12:21 +0000
> 
> Since the PUT is creating a new resource corresponding to the provided 
> URL (/destinationObject) it seems like a valid use of PUT to me. Is the 

So far, yes.

> problem the fact that the PUT request is not providing a representation 
> for the resource (eg an XML document), but is only providing a URL to 
> the representation (via the x-amz-copy-source header)?

Correct. An important aspect of good use of HTTP is that the message is 
self-descriptive. This one isn't anymore -- any recipient that isn't 
aware of the Amazon extension will simply create an empty resource. As 
such, it creates a close coupling between client and server (and it may 
also confuse intermediates).

> Again, sorry if this question is hopelessly naive.

No, it's always good to ask if something wasn't clear in the first case.

BR, Julian
